Authors:
Ling-Yun Chen, J. K. Muchuku, G. W. Hu, Y. Xue, Qing-Feng
Wang
Title:
Phylogeography of Haplocarpha rueppelii (Asteraceae) suggests
a geographical barrier between Mt Kenya and Mt Aberdare since the
Pleistocene
Keywords:
East Africa, afro-montane, afro-alpine, gene flow,
phylogeography, geographical barrier, Haplocarpha rueppellii
Abstract:
Haplocarpha rueppelii is mainly distributed in the alpine
grassland and moorland of East Africa. In this study, we sampled 61
individuals of 6 populations from East Africa, viz.Â Mts. Elgon,
Aberdare, Kenya, Kilimanjaro and Bale mountains. We sequenced 1 nuclear
and 3 chloroplast DNA fragments, and conducted phylogenetic analysis,
divergence time estimation, principal coordinate analysis and gene flow
analysis to investigate the phylogeographic structure of this species.
The results suggest that the species consists of two major groups, one
includes the populations from Mts. Elgon, Aberdare and Bale, the other
from Mts. Kenya and Kilimanjaro. The results also support that the
character of multicellular hairs is mutable and therefore no change of
the taxonomic concept of this species is needed. The species has
established in Mts. Kenya and Aberdare one million years ago, however,
its migration rate between the two mountains was low as showed by gene
flow analysis. Therefore, a barrier for plant migration and gene flow
was suggested to exist between Mts. Aberdare and Kenya, which is
different from previous studies that show close relationship between the
two mountains. In addition, diversification of this species seems not to
be affected by the East African Rift Valley. This study reveals an
unreported geographic barrier in East Africa using molecular data, and
sheds light on plant phylogeography of the area.
